awd_titl_txt: Prehistoric Native Copper Technology in Northwest North America: Innovation, Diffusion, and Heritage
awd_abstract_narration:
The existence of three distinct regions within northwest North America (central Arctic, western Subarctic, and Northwest Coast) with sources of native copper and evidence for its prehistoric use provides the opportunity for a comparative study of technological change related to the innovation of a single material among socio-politically diverse groups of hunter-gatherers. A collaborative interdisciplinary team with backgrounds in northern archaeology and ethnography, geology, and materials science will undertake a three-year program of research investigating native copper innovation, and its relationship to emergent social complexity (i.e., the development of hereditary rank), among northwest North American hunter-gatherers. Naturally occurring pure native copper was used by indigenous groups throughout the region for tools, weapons, and objects of personal adornment. This latter use has been traditionally viewed by archaeologists as attempts to display wealth using prestige goods (prestige technology) and as a result, and similar to discussions of prehistoric metallurgy in general, the use of native copper in these regions has been associated with emergent social complexity. 

Intra- and inter-regional spatial analysis of sources and artifacts, compositional analysis of artifacts in museum collections, detailed experimental studies of copper-working manufacturing, and oral history collected in collaboration with the Ahtna community, will provide quantitative and qualitative data on native copper innovation. These data will be integrated using a design theory framework that will provide a holistic multi-scalar understanding of the benefits and constraints associated with the adoption of this technology by hunter-gatherers in different social and environmental contexts. Though focused on innovation surrounding the use of a specific material among hunter-gatherers, this project will contribute to more general anthropological discussions of innovation and will generate data for use in developing models of technological innovation for future testing. Additionally, the project includes significant opportunities for interdisciplinary graduate and undergraduate education, training, and hands-on research, and opportunities for multi-generational engagement with the Ahtna community.

por.por_cntn:
One of the major outcomes of this project was the analysis of over 2,000 copper artifacts from nearly 300 sites across Alaska, Yukon, British Columbia, Northwest Territories, and Nunavut. We collected both metric and chemical compositional data on this material as well as information on archaeological context. While this large dataset is still undergoing analysis for future publications we have some preliminary results as well as results from other project activitie that address native copper metallurgical innovation and multiple scales, as well as potential for future provenance research. 

As reported by NSF funded graduated student Matthew Pike (Pike et al. 2019), a Path Distance model for the acquistion of native copper across this region appears to be a good proxy for actual provenance research in developing hyptheses about native copper innovation. Some of the hypotheses developed using this model for future testing include: How does copper use far from sources reflect conservation practices and to what extent can the location of copper-working sites better explain distribution patterns than actual geological sources. Though geochemical sourcing of native copper is impractical due to the number of potential sources, as part fo this project a pilot study was undertaken to assess whether different native copper sources could be differentiated from each other based on Pb isotope values (Cooper and Simonetti 2021). We found that gelogical native copper in Alaska and Yukon does have a different Pb isotopic signature than native copper from the Canadian Arctic. This means it would be possible to delineate where copper from one area falls out of use and is replaced by copper from the other source area. These results relate to the potential to learn more about how native copper innovation in these adjacent regions might be related to each other. 

In looking at the artifact and site level of investigation into native copper metallurgy, a copper working experiment was carried out with two undergraduate students (Cooper et al. 2015). This study supported the idea that individuals with no experience making copper objects (especially people accustomed to making other tools by hand) could quickly learn to make basic shapes using a lithic tool kit and a fire for annealing. Skill was not a technological hurdle in the adoption of native copper metallurgy by Indigenous Peoples across the Wester Arctic and Subarctic and Northwest Coast. 

This project additionally highlighted the discrepancy in previous thinking regarding the use of copper on the Northwest Coast. An analysis of precontact copper use in British Columbia (Cooper et al. 2020) demonstrated that prior to native copper innovation in Alaska and Yukon, approximately 1,000 years ago, copper was being incorporated into human burial ritual in south about 1,000 years earlier. This earlier material must be the result of a separate instance of in-situ native copper innovation, or it was imported from elsewhere with Hopewell being the only other possibility. Additional research in other regions may eventually help answer this questions.  

This project included community engagement and educational outreach targeted at Indigenous communities with historic ties to native copper use across this region. Copper-working activities were conducted in the Ahtna coummunity (Klutina and Chitina Culture Camps, and Archaeology Camp in Glennall), with the Kwanlin Dun Cultural Center in Whitehorse, Yukon, and in Cambridge Bay and Kugluktuk in Nunavut. The latter was supported in part by graduate student Matthew Pike's NSF DDRIG. Additionally, we worked with the Alaska Native Science and Engineering Program on two separate occaions delivering science and engineering themed education on past metallurgical innovation by Alaska Native people to a total of three classes of students.

While the goal of reconstructing native copper working and innovation at the Gulkana site was only partially achieved (see above experimental copper-working), this project has helped to launch current graduate student Emily Flether's research using computational methods to make data from the Gulakan site excavations more accessible to the Ahtna community and scholrs. 

The research funded by this grant also provided opportunities to collaborate with other northern researchers in understanding the use of native and trade copper at numerous sites. The pxrf purchased as part fo this grant coupled with the experience using this and othe rmaterials analysis methods allowed me to consult on the analysis of copper metal artifacts from: Cape Espenberg (Cooper et al. 2016), the Yukon (Thomas et al. 2017), British Columbia (Cooper et al. 2017), and the Columbia River (Cooper et al. 2016). See image for references.
